title: Are sanitize and sterilize the same thing? - Quora

response.answer_text: Not even close. To sterilize (in your question’s context) is to eliminate all life and render non-living biopathogens (virii, and prions if we’re lucky) “biologically inert”. Full stop. To sanitize is to ensure for the moment that unwanted living pathogens are subdued to the point that they’re unlikely to be any problem at all until long after we need them out of the way. We sanitize when cleaning home beer-brewing equipment, and we *sterilize* when we safely can meat, shellfish, or mushrooms to be stored. Otherwise, we risk our lives just eating and drinking.

Sanitizing should not be confused with sterilizing. While sanitizing reduces microorganisms to a safe level, sterilizing removes all microorganisms from an item. Sterilizing is not often performed in a commercial kitchen environment, but is used in places like hospital operating rooms.
Sanitizing is more like regular cleaning. Sterilizing is more like something has to stay perfectly clean, probably wrapped in plastic.
